summary:
Hi, I'm Harrison! I'm a current student at Princeton University majoring in Chemical and Biological Engineering. As an aspiring medicinal researcher, I am motivated to pursue the chemical and biological sciences and their pharmaceutical applications. My research interests range from drug discovery to synthetic biology to pharmaceutical business management.

If you’d like to connect, shoot me a message at hx2004@princeton.edu!

projects.description:
Won the 2nd place award in Computer Science / Mathematics category in Contra Costa County Science and Engineering Fair.
Developed a sentiment analysis algorithm and app that used natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning neural networks to analyze entire written journals of patients to determine their mental stability and possible conditions.
projects.title: BetweenTheLines: Mental Health  Detection Using Neural Networks and Sentiment Analysis
Direct Deoxyfluorination of Alcohols via In Situ Alcohol Activation

publications.description: The treatment of neurological diseases has evolved to include neuroactive alkaloids isolated from naturally occurring phytochemical sources. While some of these compounds have gone on to clinical use themselves, others have inspired the development of synthetic analogs, which might possess greater potency or better pharmacological features than the natural product itself. One such naturally occurring alkaloid, physostigmine, which is found in the Calabar bean plant Physostigma venenosum, has been demonstrated to be a potent cholinesterase inhibitor. However, some of physostigmine's characteristics limit its therapeutic potential, prompting the development of rivastigmine, a similarly structured synthetic compound. The research in our group focused on the synthetic optimization of rivastigmine and its analogs, utilizing computer modeling and biological assays to determine the most favorable analog for inhibition of acetylcholinesterase (AChE), the enzyme that breaks down the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) to terminate neuronal transmission and signaling between synapses. Patients with Alzheimer’s Disease have lower levels of ACh, which has been associated with symptoms like memory impairment and confusion. The inhibition of AChE allows for ACh accumulation and continued signaling in parasympathetic nervous system. Through our studies, we determined that rivastigmine and its analogs were less effective at inhibiting AChE than physostigmine, and their biological activity is governed by sterics.
publications.name: Modular mimics of neuroactive alkaloids - design, synthesis, and cholinesterase inhibitory activity of rivastigmine analogs

publications.description: For centuries, neuroactive alkaloids isolated from naturally occurring phytochemical sources have been crucial in the identification and optimization of small molecules with potency in treating neurological disorders. While some of these compounds have gone on to clinical use themselves, others have inspired the development of synthetic analogs, which might possess greater potency or better pharmacological features than the natural product itself. One such naturally occurring alkaloid, physostigmine, which is found in the calabar bean plant _Physostigma venenosum_, has been demonstrated to be a potent cholinesterase inhibitor. However, some of physostigmine's characteristics limit its therapeutic potential, prompting the development of its synthetic counterpart, rivastigmine. The research in our group focused on the synthetic optimization of rivastigmine and its analogs, utilizing computer modeling and biological assays to determine the most favorable analog for inhibition of acetylcholinesterase (AChE). Through such studies, it was determined that rivastigmine and its analogs were less effective at inhibiting AChE than physostigmine, and their biological activity is governed by sterics, prompting us to pursue three routes: the synthesis of S-enantiopure versions of our analogs, the synthesis of analogs with less steric hindrance, and the study of biological activity for all analogs on both cholinesterase enzymes to determine enzyme selectivity.
publications.name: Proceedings of the American Chemical Society Fall 2022 Intl. Conference - Modular mimics of neuroactive alkaloids: Design, synthesis, cholinesterase inhibitory activity, and sterics study of novel rivastigmine analogs

publications.description: Andrographolide, a labdane diterpenoid extracted from Andrographis paniculata, has been investigated as a therapeutic lead for colorectal cancer, multiple sclerosis, and other diseases. Namely, andrographolide has been found to exert its biological activity through inhibition of Nf-kB, a transcription factor at the crossroads of a myriad of cell signaling pathways, including those pertaining to tumor survival and metastasis. Synthesis of derivatives of the natural product has the potential to create analogs and prodrugs of the compound that could improve tolerability, selectivity, and potency. Here we present the synthesis of C-ring modified andrographolide analogs with altered Michael acceptor properties, as well as a series of acid hydrolyzable acetal and ketal analogs, including efforts towards an andrographolide and antibody drug conjugate (ADC) which we assay for controlled delivery and release. We use a quantitative reverse transcriptase PCR (qRT-PCR) assay as a proxy for Nf-kB regulated gene expression.
publications.name: Proceedings of the American Chemical Society Fall 2022 Intl. Conference - Reactivity informed design, synthesis, and targeted delivery of andrographolide and analogs, Nf-kB regulated natural products for cancer treatment and degenerative diseases

message.text: Thank you Dr. Wittenberg! It was really interesting to hear about your career progression from biophysics to neuroscience to data science. I really enjoyed the talk and I appreciate the insights you provided!

Yesterday, we had a great talk from Gayle Wittenberg, Ph.D.. She discussed her work at The Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson as the Vice President of Neuroscience Data Science and Digital Health. It was fascinating to hear about her career progression and how she and her team are able to integrate the sciences with computational methods. Thank you so much Dr. Wittenberg for coming to talk with us!

This was such a great event to attend. I learned so much from students from Columbia as well as graduate students from the local area. Thank you so much to Dimension for hosting us in your beautiful office!

We held our NYC Biotech Student Meetup yesterday! It was a great opportunity to meet other students spanning a broad range of interests from machine learning to venture capital in biotech. Thank you so much to Dimension for hosting this event! We really appreciate your help and hope to host more events like this to help students connect in the future!
Check this event out! It’d be a great way to learn more about biotech and meet some new people!

The Princeton Biotech Group is hosting a meeting for ALL students (both undergrad & grad, even non-Princeton students) interested in biotech & VC at Dimension’s NYC office on April 4th from 6-8pm! Dinner and drinks will be served! Come to make connections with other students in biotech community and learn about any new trends in biotech and VC!

I’m happy to share that I’ll be joining the Conway Lab at Princeton University as an Undergraduate Research Assistant. I'm really excited to learn more about the realm of biological research, from exploring genetic databases for protein analysis to working in the wet lab synthesizing target proteins.

commentary.text: Congratulations Noah! This is some really interesting chemistry!
